description:
CEO of Wolfprint 3D, Timmu Toke, is visiting Columbia to talk about the technology that powers the Luna Scanner. His work is helping bring people closer to VR experiences. Anyone interested in virtual reality, augmented reality, or 3D scanning should come.

Wolfprint 3D develops high-quality 3D scanning technology to create realistic virtual reality avatars. Gaming and VR experiences can be enhanced thanks to their precise 3D models. Visit http://wolfprint3d.com for more.
title: VR/3D Scanning Tech Talk with Wolfprint 3D

description:
Kick back, relax, and travel back in time with the singers and instrumentalists of Columbia Bach Society, as we take you on a musical journey through the ages.

Time: 8:00 PM
Location: Wallach Hall Main Lounge
Admission: Open to everyone, and FREE.
If you do not have access to Columbia University residence halls, please RSVP with the form below!
https://goo.gl/forms/aZnuu7rbFt8ShG9H3

The talented musicians of Columbia Bach Society will be showcasing a wide variety of genres, time periods, and the evolution of music. Featured genres will include classical, jazz, electronic, and MORE.

Perfect for those who like history, those who like music, those who like music history, or those who just want a fun night of good music. In other words, anyone and everyone is welcome!
title: BachSoc Presents: Music Through The Ages

description: Come chill with our BME department's very own Dr. Hess, whose work is concerned with "engineering at the molecular scale, in particular the design of active nanosystems incorporating biomolecular motors, the study of active self-assembly, and the investigation of protein-resistant polymer coatings."  Ask him about anything from his career path to his go-to dinner spots.
title: Fun with Faculty: Dr. Hess!
location: BME Conference Room, 3rd Floor Mudd (Engineering Terrace), Follow the Signs

description:
CCSC, SGA, GSSC, and ESC present the annual Tree Lighting Ceremony on Thursday, December 1st at 6PM! Come celebrate Columbia's cherished winter tradition with friends!

We will serve hot chocolate and cider and have amazing Columbia swag starting at 5:30pm. At 6, there will be performances from a cappella groups, special words from your student councils, and of course, the count down for the tree lighting itself!

**Want a chance to perform at Tree Lighting? We invite and encourage all Acappella groups to fill out this form to express interest in auditioning for a spot: https://goo.gl/forms/F6ksyWNAl96hzXn13

**SENIORS! Don't forget to attend the Senior Winter Gala after the ceremonies! More details to come. 

**CC STUDENTS!
Join fellow Columbians in an annual tradition hosted by the Columbia College Alumni Association! Watch as College Walk's trees are lit up, then join friends and College alumni in the Journalism School's World Room for a Winter Celebration! Enjoy food, drinks and musical performances. This event is free for College students.

And finally, shout out to Helen Yu for the wonderful cover photo and poster design! 

We can't wait to see everyone there!
title: CU Tree Lighting Ceremony 2016

description:
'Twas the night before Tree Lighting and there were free beanies!

Come by the Lerner Party Space 9:00 PM on Wednesday for some delicious holiday desserts and treats, a stylin' photobooth, and FREE Columbia College beanies!

Can't wait to see you there, and to join everyone outside on Low Plaza for the CU Tree Lighting Ceremony 2016 on Thursday!

description:

If you want to cook for the event, please sign up here! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1YyppHjsQ_Cqu7QIJJcMDizbDDa2MXKenMXHzQSQFN3Q/edit#gid=0
title: CU Culinary Society: Comfort Food Study Break

description:
Throughout the year, the department will host events to discuss a variety of post graduation options. Our second event will focus on full time Research Assistant positions. The session will begin with a brief discussion of the types of full-time RA opportunities and the process through which students obtain such jobs.  All of these positions will require data analysis skills. The main part of the evening will be a tutorial covering common tasks related to data manipulation and analysis using Stata. These examples are inspired by the "Stata tests" that are often used during interview processes for RA jobs. The tasks cover topics such as merging data sets and using macros, loops, string functions, and datetime functions. The tutorial is intended for those who are familiar with the Stata interface and the basic commands (from Intro to Econometrics), but those who have never used Stata are also welcome to attend. Students interested in pursuing graduate work in economics are strongly encouraged to attend. 

FOOD WILL BE PROVIDED.
 
To receive information about our upcoming information sessions, please subscribe to the mailing list, econevents. To subscribe to this list follow the link 
https://lists.columbia.edu/mailman/listinfo/econevents
and simply follow the directions there to subscribe yourself to the list.
title: Economics Dept.: Research Assistant Information Session

description:
Already have a full-time job offer? Considering getting your MBA in the future and want to get a head-start? Even if you're an underclassman just starting to explore the idea of business school, it's never too early to start preparing.

The Columbia Economics Society is hosting an admissions seminar with Chioma Isiadinso, CEO of MBA admissions consulting firm EXPARTUS and former Harvard admissions board member, to help Columbia students discover how to apply successfully to the Harvard 2+2 MBA program. This seminar will also cover other early career admissions options at top schools like Stanford Graduate School of Business and Yale School of Management.

***PLEASE RSVP by clicking "Going" on this event, and use the following link to secure a spot at the event: 
http://www.expartus.com/seminar

The event is FREE to students and will teach applicants how to apply with confidence and when to apply to elite MBA programs to get an edge in the application process. A 1-hour seminar is typically priced at $350.

Here’s what you’ll learn at this seminar: 
• How to assess whether you should apply to the 2+2 program or postpone your application
• Mistakes 2+2 applicants make and how to avoid them
• Who to use for recommenders
• Other early career application programs (Stanford and Yale)
• And much more

We look forward to seeing you there!

-----------------------------------


A note from Chioma Isiadinso: 

I am the CEO of EXPARTUS (www.expartus.com), an admissions consulting and personal branding company that has helped thousands of clients from over 200 countries to gain admission at the world’s best business schools. 

We help our clients discover their personal brand and communicate it effectively through their application, and this unique branding method sets EXPARTUS apart. 

As a former Harvard Business School admissions board member and former director of admissions at Carnegie Mellon University, I have seen firsthand the power of personal branding in helping applicants get admitted to top schools without necessarily being the obvious choice based on their academic and professional credentials. 

Top schools want diversity. They want individuals who are passionate and who will change the world. Applicants who are able to make a strong case that they will impact their world and that they are authentic and engaged individuals will always stand out from their competition. This is what we teach our clients at EXPARTUS. 

After 20 years in the admissions industry I know that personal branding works. I know that authenticity wins. Helping thousands of clients over the nearly 15 years of leading EXPARTUS, with my incredible team of consultants, has proven to me that it’s not about being perfect. It’s not about just having the highest test scores. It’s about self-awareness; helping applicants discover who they are and the impact they want to have in the world. 

In addition to my leadership responsibilities at EXPARTUS, I am an international speaker on the subject of education and admissions and have presented to organizations like the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), JP Morgan, and Bank of America. I am the author of "The Best Business Schools' Admissions Secrets" and provide interviews to the Financial Times, the New York Times, CNBC, and Bloomberg BusinessWeek.com.
title: Early MBA Admissions Secrets- Q&A with ex-HBS Admissions Officer

description: Are you considering majoring in economics? Interested in research, law, finance, venture capitalism, or sustainable development? Join Columbia Economics Society for a discussion with CU upperclassmen pursuing or experienced in these fields to gain a better understanding for the possibilities open to econ majors and learn how to make the most out of Columbia to excel in these areas!
title: So You Want to be an Econ Major?

description:
Columbia University's startup accelerator, Almaworks, will be hosting a demo day for its Fall 2016 graduating class. For the past few months, these startups have been hacking, scaling, and hustling to prepare their pitches for this capstone event. This event is open to the public and requires no prior registration.

Come watch some of the top student startups in Columbia pitch to the NYC startup community and then attend the post-pitch dinner session where you will be able to talk with all the teams in the 3rd Almaworks class. Free food and refreshments will be served.

Learn more about Almaworks at www.alma.works and learn more about CORE at www.coreatcu.com.

location: Davis Auditorium, CEPSR (1st Floor, 530 West 120th Street)

description:
We're going to have a thoughtful discussion touching on the implications of Duterte's Presidency, looking specifically at human rights violations with his war on drugs, and the future of US-Phillippines relations.

For some more information regarding this topic, please consider the following articles. We will also be posting articles everyday the week leading up to this event in hopes of an engaging, informed discussion.

https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/philippines/2016-05-31/philippine-punisher-s-rise

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/10/world/asia/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-obama.html?smid=fb-share&_r=0

http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21707167-new-president-may-undo-economic-gains-recent-years-sceptred-bile
title: Discussion: The Implications of Rodrigo Duterte's Presidency

description: A man who had famously survived more than 600 assassination attempts, Fidel Castro died early on Saturday morning, leaving behind a country he had ruled for nearly half a century. Castro is famous for forced interrogations, violations of human rights, and the oppression of a people, many of whom fled to the United States for safety. Despite that, Castro remains a popular figure in Cuba itself, and has a complicated relationship with the rights of People of Color within the Caribbean. In many nations in South America, he and Che Guevara are celebrated as liberators. So our discussion this week focuses on this: Was Castro simply another malevolent dictator? Or was he a positive figure in Cuban history who liberated a people from an oppressive puppet dictatorship?
title: Resolved: Fidel Castro's Dictatorship was a reflection of the Cuban People's beliefs

description:
Science is not an individual sport—teams are the heart of public health and the backbone of ground-breaking achievements. The 2016-2017 Grand Rounds series brings together collaborators from across the Mailman School's disciplines and portfolios for discussions about how interdisciplinary teams are breaking down silos to to take on issues including obesity, climate change, and racism and violence. 

November's event - titled "A Pipeline Approach to Team Science: From Concepts to Communities" - will feature a discussion with Raygine DiAquoi, Director of the Office of Diversity, Culture, and Inclusion and Assistant Professor of Sociomedical Sciences, and Gina Wingood, Sidney and Helaine Lerner Professor of Public Health in Sociomedical Sciences.

If you're not able to attend in person, this event will be livestreamed here: https://livestream.com/mailman/communities and we encourage you to tweet and follow along the conversation using #TeamScience.
title: Pipeline Approach to Team Science: From Concepts to Communities

description:
BSO's biggest event of the year, the Kwanzaa Ball, is a semi-formal event which unites and uplifts our community annually around the principles of Kwanzaa. This year's Ball will be centered around the theme of Kujichagulia, or Self Determination. Self- Determination in this context is, " to define ourselves, name ourselves, create for ourselves and speak for ourselves" 

The event will feature a cocktail hour, soul food dinner, student performances and a keynote address from Professor Natasha Lightfoot.

Entry is FREE for all. A ticket guarantees food, NOT entry. 
Tickets will be available at the TIC from 12/2 to 12/9. Non- CUID are free to attend this event as well but they MUST be on the guest list otherwise they will NOT be guaranteed a spot. MUST BRING STUDENT ID FOR ADMISSION. 

CUID includes ALL of Columbia's schools (Barnard, GS, TC, Journalism etc) 

**You need not celebrate Kwanzaa to attend.**
**Semi Formal dress code**
title: Black Candle Ball: A Tribute to Kwanzaa

title: CUEBS Recycling Workshop

This event is free but an advance RSVP is required. https://columbiabarnardhillel.org/event/jerusalem-meet-up/

description:
The power shift is happening in North Korea NOW and it's time to get involved. First step: be informed. Join CU Link and Professor Andrew Nathan on a panel discussion about Kim Jung Un, North Korea-China relations, and what the new US presidency means for the future of North Korean politics. 

***Free Korean Food will be served!!***

Andrew J. Nathan is Class of 1919 Professor of Political Science at Columbia University. His teaching and research interests include Chinese politics and foreign policy, the comparative study of political participation and political culture, and human rights. 

Nathan is chair of the steering committee of the Center for the Study of Human Rights and chair of the Morningside Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Columbia. He served as chair of the Department of Political Science, 2003-2006, chair of the Executive Committee of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, 2002-2003, and director of the Weatherhead East Asian Institute, 1991-1995.
title: With Andrew Nathan: North Korean Power Dynamics (Dinner Served!)

description:
AT CAPACITY

Join us at Japan Society for an exclusive tour of their current exhibition, Simon Starling: At Twilight (After W. B. Yeats' Noh Reincarnation), led by Curator of Exhibition Interpretation Michael Chagnon.

At the height of WWI, poet W. B. Yeats collaborated with members of the avant garde to stage his Japanese noh inspired dance play At the Hawk's Well (1916). To mark its centennial, Turner Prize winner Simon Starling reinterprets this production in an exhibition that illustrates the impact of noh on Western Modernism. Newly created masks, costumes, and a dance on video are paired with works by the 20th-century masters connected to Yeats' play, bringing to life Starling's irrepressible inventiveness.

After the tour, stick around for Japan Society's Escape East Happy Hour to explore the exhibition more on your own and enjoy live music and complimentary sake!

This event is open only to current Columbia students, faculty, and staff.
title: Museum Meetup: Japan Society

description:
Visitors are invited to join exhibiting artist Leah Raintree on an hour-long walk through the Museum and her current exhibition, Another Land: After Noguchi. This conversational tour will introduce you to the Museum’s collection, and Raintree’s experience developing a relationship between her own work and Isamu Noguchi’s sculptures through photography. 

Free with Museum admission. Advance reservations are not required. 

Image: Installation view, Leah Raintree, Another Land: After Noguchi. Photo: Nicholas Knight.
title: Museum Tour with Artist Leah Raintree

description:
Undergrad Career Prep Week: December 5-9
 
Planning to spend winter break searching for a summer internship or full-time job? Whether you’re just getting started or your search is well underway, this series of career workshops will help you navigate your next steps with ease. From building memorable connections with professionals and employers to crafting your resume and cover letter, CCE is here to help! RSVP below to reserve your spot in any of these workshops. All workshops will be held from 12:30pm-1pm
 
Open to all Undergrads
Monday, December 5: LionSHARE
Tuesday, December 6: Resumes and Cover Letters - Co-sponsored by The American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME)
Wednesday, December 7: LinkedIn Profile Development - Co-sponsored by the Engineering Student Council (ESC)
Thursday, December 8: Building a Professional Network - Co-sponsored by the CCSC 2020 Class Council and the General Studies Student Council (GSSC)
Friday, December 9: Interviewing Skills - Co-sponsored by the General Studies Student Council (GSSC)
 
Learn about internship opportunities through CCE!
 
First Years Only Friday, December 9: Internships, Externships and First-Year Partnerships with CCE Information Session, 10:30-11:30am
            Co-sponsored by the ESC 2020 Class Council and the CCSC 2020 Class Council
 
All Undergrads Friday, December 9: CCE Summer Internship Programs Information Session: CEO, CCASSIP, CU GO, SCCEN & STEP, 3-4pm
title: CCE Undergrad Career Prep Week
location: The Center for Career Education, Columbia University

description:
Do you love the food, especially the pies, on Thanksgiving? Do you wish Thanksgiving break was longer than four days? Well the lovely folks from Engineers Without Borders Ghana agree. While we can't do anything to make break longer, we can do something about the pie. The Wednesday after Thanksgiving break we are delivering delicious slices of pumpkin and apple pie to your dorm room between 8 and 9pm! It is just $2 a slice, or $3 à la mode. Ordering is simple, just fill out the form below and Venmo @NoahLarky for your yummy pie.

https://goo.gl/forms/dqC7cFPxorRSgBlF2

Don't want pie but want to support our work? Please consider donating using the link below.
https://support.ewb-usa.org/fundraise?fcid=713453
title: Make Thanksgiving Last! Pie Fundraiser
location: Engineers Without Borders-USA CU Ghana Program

description:
Last spring, the Senate Student Affairs Committee launched a new subcommittee for student's living with disabilities. The Subcommittee for Student's with Disabilities has two main goals: 1) improve the quality of life of CU students living with disabilities and 2) help spread awareness about what it means to live and study at Columbia while living with a disability. 

Join us on Saturday, December 3rd, as we celebrate the United Nations International Day of Persons with Disabilities.  We will be socializing, sharing resources, raising awareness, and hearing from distinguished speakers.....yes there will be food, and lots of it. 

From 1-4, you can come by the Lowe steps to go on a scavenger hunt through the tunnels below campus. Make your way through the tunnels and back to Lowe steps to get your prize....you might also learn a thing or two about living with disabilities :-)

From 5-7, in Fairchild 601, we will be catering a social gathering, followed by a panel of speakers who each have a unique perspective that will help foster greater awareness on campus of the lives of students living with disabilities.

**Columbia University makes every effort to accommodate individuals with disabilities. If you require disability accommodations to attend this event, please contact Disability Services at 212-854-2388 or disability@columbia.edu at least 5 days in advance of the event.**
title: UN International Day of Persons with Disabilities @Columbia University

description:
The GSSC Food Bank is accepting non-perishable food donations to continue its efforts to combat food insecurity on campus. Starting this Tuesday, our representatives will be collecting non-perishable food donations every Tuesday from 11AM to 2PM in front of Lerner Hall. 

These are the items we need the most:
- Plastic Reusable Bags 
- Rice (Brown or White)
- Canned fruits
- Canned vegetables
- Evaporated Milk 
- Cereal 
- Instant Oatmeal
- Apple Sauce 
- Peanut Butter 
- Pasta Sauce
- Pasta
- Any non-perishable food geared towards students with families (e.g. baby food, formula, etc.)

Don't forget: fighting food insecurity on campus starts with you!
title: Giving Tuesdays

description:
If you are going to travel abroad, you may need to get a new travel signature on your I-20 or DS-2019 before you leave. Check the bottom of page 2 of the F-1 I-20 form or page 1 of the J-1 DS-2019: If you don’t have a signature there, you need to get one. If you do have a signature, the date on it must be less than 12 months old from the date on which you will return. This is the second of two ISSO signing sessions held on campus for your convenience. 
● If your current signature is not expiring before your return date, do not come to get one at this time.
title: ISSO Travel Signatures for International Students
